ygData.subject: Current NEAT state of the art for benchmarking
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello all, I m working on some extensions to NEAT and want to ensure I m making fair comparisons to the state of the art, not only the algorithm as it was

X-eGroups-From: Adam Gaier <adam.gaier@...>
Subject: Current NEAT state of the art for benchmarking
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=231866928; y=KcOXfLV9ns1-iG3Rn95uTWHRTT_gpTzdJ9WrsPy2YO-Zigy2Tmjc
From: Adam Gaier <adam.ga@...>


--f403045cf0fe51cf1a055c719749
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"

Hello all,

I'm working on some extensions to NEAT and want to ensure I'm making fair
comparisons to the state of the art, not only the algorithm as it was
presented 15 years ago. What is the current state in terms of benchmarking?

Is cart-pole still a good/common benchmark?

In the original NEAT paper very large population sizes and a small number
of generations are used, but this doesn't seem to be the case in more
recent use cases. Is there a 'standard' parameter set?

Are there basic algorithmic changes I could take into account? I know in
the SharpNeat implementation there are a few speciation techniques, are any
of these widespread enough that they should be considered rather than the
original speciation approach in a publication? In many recent publications
rtNeat is used, should I be comparing to a steady-state version of NEAT?


Thanks in advance, especially to those of you who have recently published
papers using NEAT

adam gaier

--f403045cf0fe51cf1a055c719749
Content-Type: text/html; charset="UTF-8"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
